survey_system: You are an expert annotator analyzing social survey questions in climate-related discourse. Answer with exactly one of the allowed options; no explanation.

questions.wording: Cite health as main reason for cutting meat
questions.prompt: Check whether the text links reducing meat consumption to health considerations (health benefits/risks, cholesterol, weight, disease, wellness). Direction does not matter. Output YES if health is used as a reason or concern, otherwise NO.

questions.wording: Protecting animals is 'moderately' important when choosing food
questions.prompt: Check whether the text associates food choice (especially meat vs plant-based) with animal welfare/ethics (harm to animals, cruelty, rights, compassion). Direction does not matter. Output YES if animal welfare is invoked, otherwise NO.

questions.wording: Helping to reduce global warming is 'moderately' important
questions.prompt: Check whether the text links dietary choices (meat reduction/plant-based) to climate impact (global warming, emissions, carbon footprint). Direction does not matter. Output YES if climate is a stated consideration, otherwise NO.

questions.wording: Willing to eat more plant-based meat alternatives
questions.prompt: Check whether the text discusses willingness or intent to consume plant-based meat alternatives (substitutes, meat analogs). Direction does not matter (willing or unwilling both count). Output YES if intent/willingness is mentioned, otherwise NO.

questions.wording: Willing to eat less red meat
questions.prompt: Check whether the text discusses willingness or intent to reduce red meat consumption. Direction does not matter. Output YES if intent/willingness is mentioned, otherwise NO.

questions.wording: Willing to reduce dairy or use dairy alternatives
questions.prompt: Check whether the text discusses willingness or intent to reduce dairy consumption or use dairy alternatives (plant milks like soy/almond/oat, reducing dairy intake). Direction does not matter. Output YES if intent/willingness is mentioned, otherwise NO.

original_questions.wording: Willing to use dairy alternatives (soy/almond) instead of dairy milk

questions.wording: Willing to eat lab-grown meat (cell culture)
questions.prompt: Check whether the text discusses willingness or intent to eat lab-grown/cultivated meat (cell-cultured). Direction does not matter. Output YES if intent/willingness is mentioned, otherwise NO.

questions.wording: Taste is important for plant-based choices or would switch if tasted better
questions.prompt: Check whether the text links plant-based choices to taste/palatability (flavor, satisfaction, texture, taste quality as a factor or switching condition). Direction does not matter. Output YES if taste is mentioned as a factor, otherwise NO.

original_questions.wording: Taste is 'moderately' important motive for plant-based choices
Would switch if plant-based foods tasted better

questions.wording: Convenience (ease/quick prep) is 'moderately' important
questions.prompt: Check whether the text links plant-based choices to convenience/effort/time (ease of cooking, quick prep, availability, hassle). Direction does not matter. Output YES if convenience/effort is invoked, otherwise NO.

questions.wording: Would switch if plant-based foods were cheaper
questions.prompt: Check whether the text associates plant-based choices with price/cost/affordability (too expensive, cheaper, pricing barriers, value). Direction does not matter. Output YES if cost is mentioned as a factor, otherwise NO.

questions.wording: Nobody has ever asked them to eat more plant-based foods
questions.prompt: Check whether the text links plant-based eating to social prompting/normative asking (being asked/encouraged, social influence, requests from others). Direction does not matter. Output YES if social prompting/norms are mentioned, otherwise NO.

questions.wording: Barriers to plant-based eating (knowledge or buying effort)
questions.prompt: Check whether the text associates plant-based eating with barriers (knowledge/information barriers, buying effort/friction, not knowing what to buy, confusion, lack of guidance, labels, shopping difficulty, hard to find, limited options, inconvenience in purchasing). Direction does not matter. Output YES if any barrier is mentioned, otherwise NO.

original_questions.wording: Don't know what plant-based foods to buy (knowledge barrier)
Too much effort to buy plant-based foods

questions.wording: Prefer meals with meat/dairy (identity preference)
questions.prompt: Check whether the text links preference for meat/dairy to identity, tradition, or self-concept ("I'm a meat person", culture, habits, masculinity, comfort identity). Direction does not matter. Output YES if identity/tradition framing appears, otherwise NO.

questions.wording: Say EVs are better for the environment than gas cars
questions.prompt: Check whether the text links EVs to environmental impact compared to gas cars (pollution, emissions, climate, air quality, lifecycle footprint). Direction does not matter. Output YES if environment is discussed as a comparison dimension, otherwise NO.

questions.wording: Say EVs cost more up front
questions.prompt: Check whether the text associates EVs with up-front purchase price/cost to buy (sticker price, affordability, incentives, MSRP, financing). Direction does not matter. Output YES if purchase-cost is mentioned, otherwise NO.

questions.wording: Say EVs cost less to charge than fueling gas
questions.prompt: Check whether the text links EVs to operating/energy costs, especially charging cost versus gasoline fueling (cost per mile, electricity price, gas price, running costs). Direction does not matter. Output YES if charging vs fueling cost is referenced, otherwise NO.

questions.wording: Extremely/very confident U.S. will build enough chargers
questions.prompt: Check whether the text associates EV adoption with charging infrastructure availability (enough chargers, charger rollout, network density, access, buildout). Direction does not matter. Output YES if infrastructure adequacy is discussed, otherwise NO.

questions.wording: Feel EVs are more fun to drive
questions.prompt: Check whether the text links EVs to driving experience/pleasure (fun, acceleration, smoothness, quietness, performance feel). Direction does not matter. Output YES if driving-experience is mentioned, otherwise NO.

questions.wording: Believe EVs are more reliable than gas cars
questions.prompt: Check whether the text associates EVs with reliability/maintenance compared to gas cars (breakdowns, battery degradation, repairs, service, longevity). Direction does not matter. Output YES if reliability/maintenance is discussed as a dimension, otherwise NO.

questions.wording: View home solar panels as a major cost-saving addition
questions.prompt: Check whether the text associates home/residential solar panels with cost savings or financial benefits (reducing bills, saving money, return on investment, energy cost reduction). Direction does not matter. Output YES if cost-saving benefit is mentioned, otherwise NO.

questions.wording: See solar as a way to help the environment/planet

questions.wording: Believe it's difficult or impossible to recover the investment

Direction does not matter. Output YES if payback/recovery concerns are mentioned, otherwise NO.

Direction does not matter. Output YES if climate/sunshine adequacy is discussed, otherwise NO.

questions.prompt: Check whether the text discusses installer quality, trustworthiness, or qualifications for home solar (installer competence, proper credentials, quality of work, cowboy installers, choosing reliable installer, installer reputation). Direction does not matter. Output YES if installer quality/trust concerns appear, otherwise NO.

questions.wording: Received inadequate post-installation support or maintenance information
questions.prompt: Check whether the text associates home solar with post-installation support, maintenance information, or ongoing care (lack of guidance, no maintenance info, unclear how to maintain, need for support, system registration, aftercare, servicing guidance). Direction does not matter. Output YES if support/maintenance information is mentioned, otherwise NO.

questions.wording: Willing to pay for ongoing maintenance or care plans
questions.prompt: Check whether the text discusses willingness or interest in paying for home solar maintenance plans or ongoing care (subscription for maintenance, care plans, service agreements, paying for upkeep, maintenance contracts). Direction does not matter. Output YES if maintenance payment willingness appears, otherwise NO.

questions.wording: Believe their system generates what was promised or more
questions.prompt: Check whether the text discusses home solar system performance relative to expectations (meeting promises, generating expected energy, underperforming or overperforming, matching projections, actual vs promised output). Direction does not matter. Output YES if performance delivery is discussed, otherwise NO.

questions.wording: Lack confidence in using or understanding their solar system
questions.prompt: Check whether the text associates home solar with user confidence or understanding (ease of use, system complexity, unclear how it works, monitoring difficulties, understanding output, operating the system). Direction does not matter. Output YES if confidence/understanding issues appear, otherwise NO.
